page.title: 02THE HISTORY OF SEVERN STOKE
page.content: In the twelfth century, the banks of the River Severn in this area were used as a{vineyard.}This practice continued for a hundred years until a disastrous flood in 1371. In the fourteenth century a group of the local Manor Lords led by{Robert de {Brunswock}rose against the Earl of Coventry heralding fifty years of bloodshed. In the civil war the priest of Severn Stoke,{John Somers,}was shot dead in his pulpit (and the bullet holes can still be seen today!). Severn Stoke was the birthplace of a working class movement called the {"Levellers"}in 1671. They were described as "A band of rogues who did many deeds of villainry in the country".Many of their principles were subsequently overtaken by the Quakers.
